standard_metadata.standard_description: Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 or 100.

hints.content: Let's look at $0.1$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD1$ |
The number $\blueD1$ is in the tenths place, so we have one tenth.
$0.1$ can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD1}{10}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.2$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD2$ |
The number $\blueD2$ is in the tenths place, so we have two tenths.
$0.2$ can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD2}{10}$ .  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.3$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD3$ |
The number $\blueD3$ is in the tenths place, so we have three tenths.
$0.3$ can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD3}{10}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.4$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD4$ |
The number $\blueD4$ is in the tenths place, so we have four tenths.
$0.4$ can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD4}{10}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.5$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD5$ |
The number $\blueD5$ is in the tenths place, so we have five tenths.
$0.5$ can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD5}{10}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.6$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD6$ |
The number $\blueD6$ is in the tenths place, so we have six tenths.
$0.6$ can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD6}{10}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.7$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD7$ |
The number $\blueD7$ is in the tenths place, so we have seven tenths.
$0.7$ can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD7}{10}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.8$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD8$ |
The number $\blueD8$ is in the tenths place, so we have eight tenths.
$0.8$ can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD8}{10}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.9$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD9$ |
The number $\blueD9$ is in the tenths place, so we have nine tenths.
$0.9$ can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD9}{10}$.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.01$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD0$ | $\purpleC1$
We have a $\blueD0$ in the tenths place.  We can write zero tenths as $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10}$.
We have a $\purpleC1$ in the hundredths place.  We can write one hundredth as $\dfrac{\purpleC1}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC1}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& {\blueD0} + \dfrac{\purpleC1}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\purpleC1}{100} \end{align}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.02$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD0$ | $\purpleC2$
We have a $\blueD0$ in the tenths place.  We can write zero tenths as $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10}$.
We have a $\purpleC2$ in the hundredths place.  We can write two hundredths as $\dfrac{\purpleC2}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC2}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& {\blueD0} + \dfrac{\purpleC2}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\purpleC2}{100} \end{align}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.03$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD0$ | $\purpleC3$
We have a $\blueD0$ in the tenths place.  We can write zero tenths as $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10}$.
We have a $\purpleC3$ in the hundredths place.  We can write three hundredths as $\dfrac{\purpleC3}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC3}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& {\blueD0} + \dfrac{\purpleC3}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\purpleC3}{100} \end{align}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.04$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD0$ | $\purpleC4$
We have a $\blueD0$ in the tenths place.  We can write zero tenths as $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10}$.
We have a $\purpleC4$ in the hundredths place.  We can write four hundredths as $\dfrac{\purpleC4}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC4}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& {\blueD0} + \dfrac{\purpleC4}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\purpleC4}{100} \end{align}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.05$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD0$ | $\purpleC5$
We have a $\blueD0$ in the tenths place.  We can write zero tenths as $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10}$.
We have a $\purpleC5$ in the hundredths place.  We can write five hundredths as $\dfrac{\purpleC5}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC5}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& {\blueD0} + \dfrac{\purpleC5}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\purpleC5}{100} \end{align}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.06$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD0$ | $\purpleC6$
We have a $\blueD0$ in the tenths place.  We can write zero tenths as $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10}$.
We have a $\purpleC6$ in the hundredths place.  We can write six hundredths as $\dfrac{\purpleC6}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC6}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& {\blueD0} + \dfrac{\purpleC6}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\purpleC6}{100} \end{align}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.07$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD0$ | $\purpleC7$
We have a $\blueD0$ in the tenths place.  We can write zero tenths as $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10}$.
We have a $\purpleC7$ in the hundredths place.  We can write seven hundredths as $\dfrac{\purpleC7}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC7}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& {\blueD0} + \dfrac{\purpleC7}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\purpleC7}{100} \end{align}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.08$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD0$ | $\purpleC8$
We have a $\blueD0$ in the tenths place.  We can write zero tenths as $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10}$.
We have a $\purpleC8$ in the hundredths place.  We can write eight hundredths as $\dfrac{\purpleC8}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC8}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& {\blueD0} + \dfrac{\purpleC8}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\purpleC8}{100} \end{align}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.09$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD0$ | $\purpleC9$
We have a $\blueD0$ in the tenths place.  We can write zero tenths as $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10}$.
We have a $\purpleC9$ in the hundredths place.  We can write nine hundredths as $\dfrac{\purpleC9}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD0}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC9}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& {\blueD0} + \dfrac{\purpleC9}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\purpleC9}{100} \end{align}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.11$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD1$ | $\purpleC1$
The number $\blueD1$ is in the tenths place, so we have one tenth.  One tenth can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD1}{10}$.
The number $\purpleC1$ is in the hundredths place, so we have one hundredth.  One hundredth can be written as $\dfrac{\purpleC1}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD1}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC1}{100}$
$\begin{align} &= \dfrac{\blueD10}{100} + \dfrac{\purpleC1}{100} \\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD1\purpleC1}{100} \end{align}$  [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.15$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD1$ | $\purpleC5$
The number $\blueD1$ is in the tenths place, so we have one tenth.  One tenth can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD1}{10}$.
The number $\purpleC5$ is in the hundredths place, so we have five hundredths.  Five hundredths can be written as $\dfrac{\purpleC5}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD1}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC5}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& \dfrac{\blueD10}{100} + \dfrac{\purpleC5}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\blueD1\purpleC5}{100} \end{align}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.19$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD1$ | $\purpleC9$
The number $\blueD1$ is in the tenths place, so we have one tenth.  One tenth can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD1}{10}$.
The number $\purpleC9$ is in the hundredths place, so we have nine hundredths.  Nine hundredths can be written as $\dfrac{\purpleC9}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD1}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC9}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& \dfrac{\blueD10}{100} + \dfrac{\purpleC9}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\blueD1\purpleC9}{100} \end{align}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.24$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD2$ | $\purpleC4$
The number $\blueD2$ is in the tenths place, so we have two tenths.  Two tenths can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD2}{10}$.
The number $\purpleC4$ is in the hundredths place, so we have four hundredths.  Four hundredths can be written as $\dfrac{\purpleC4}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD2}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC4}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& \dfrac{\blueD20}{100} + \dfrac{\purpleC4}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\blueD2\purpleC4}{100} \end{align}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.29$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD2$ | $\purpleC9$
The number $\blueD2$ is in the tenths place, so we have two tenths.  Two tenths can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD2}{10}$.
The number $\purpleC9$ is in the hundredths place, so we have nine hundredths.  Nine hundredths can be written as $\dfrac{\purpleC9}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD2}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC9}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& \dfrac{\blueD20}{100} + \dfrac{\purpleC9}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\blueD2\purpleC9}{100} \end{align}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.38$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD3$ | $\purpleC8$
The number $\blueD3$ is in the tenths place, so we have three tenths.  Three tenths can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD3}{10}$.
The number $\purpleC8$ is in the hundredths place, so we have eight hundredths.  Eight hundredths can be written as $\dfrac{\purpleC8}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD3}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC8}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& \dfrac{\blueD30}{100} + \dfrac{\purpleC8}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\blueD3\purpleC8}{100} \end{align}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.46$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD4$ | $\purpleC6$
The number $\blueD4$ is in the tenths place, so we have four tenths.  Four tenths can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD4}{10}$.
The number $\purpleC6$ is in the hundredths place, so we have six hundredths.   Six hundredths can be written as $\dfrac{\purpleC6}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD4}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC6}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& \dfrac{\blueD40}{100} + \dfrac{\purpleC6}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\blueD4\purpleC6}{100} \end{align}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.53$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD5$ | $\purpleC3$
The number $\blueD5$ is in the tenths place, so we have five tenths.  Five tenths can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD5}{10}$.
The number $\purpleC3$ is in the hundredths place, so we have three hundredths.  Three hundredths can be written as $\dfrac{\purpleC3}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD5}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC3}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& \dfrac{\blueD50}{100} + \dfrac{\purpleC3}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\blueD5\purpleC3}{100} \end{align}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.58$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD5$ | $\purpleC8$
The number $\blueD5$ is in the tenths place, so we have five tenths.  Five tenths can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD5}{10}$.
The number $\purpleC8$ is in the hundredths place, so we have eight hundredths.  Eight hundredths can be written as $\dfrac{\purpleC8}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD5}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC8}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& \dfrac{\blueD50}{100} + \dfrac{\purpleC8}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\blueD5\purpleC8}{100} \end{align}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.63$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD6$ | $\purpleC3$
The number $\blueD6$ is in the tenths place, so we have six tenths.  Six tenths can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD6}{10}$.
The number $\purpleC3$ is in the hundredths place, so we have three hundredths.  Three hundredths can be written as $\dfrac{\purpleC3}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD6}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC3}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& \dfrac{\blueD60}{100} + \dfrac{\purpleC3}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\blueD6\purpleC3}{100} \end{align}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.78$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD7$ | $\purpleC8$
The number $\blueD7$ is in the tenths place, so we have seven tenths.  Seven tenths can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD7}{10}$.
The number $\purpleC8$ is in the hundredths place, so we have eight hundredths.  Eight hundredths can be written as $\dfrac{\purpleC8}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD7}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC8}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& \dfrac{\blueD70}{100} + \dfrac{\purpleC8}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\blueD7\purpleC8}{100} \end{align}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.82$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD8$ | $\purpleC2$
The number $\blueD8$ is in the tenths place, so we have eight tenths.  Eight tenths can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD8}{10}$.
The number $\purpleC2$ is in the hundredths place, so we have two hundredths.  Two hundredths can be written as $\dfrac{\purpleC2}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD8}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC2}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& \dfrac{\blueD80}{100} + \dfrac{\purpleC2}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\blueD8\purpleC2}{100} \end{align}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]
Let's look at $0.96$ on a place value table.  Ones |. | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:   $0$ | .| $\blueD9$ | $\purpleC6$
The number $\blueD9$ is in the tenths place, so we have nine tenths.  Nine tenths can be written as $\dfrac{\blueD9}{10}$.
The number $\purpleC6$ is in the hundredths place, so we have six hundredths.  Six hundredths can be written as $\dfrac{\purpleC6}{100}$.
Add the two parts together.   $\dfrac{\blueD9}{10} + \dfrac{\purpleC6}{100}$
$\begin{align} =& \dfrac{\blueD90}{100} + \dfrac{\purpleC6}{100}\\\\ =& \dfrac{\blueD9\purpleC6}{100} \end{align}$   [[☃ explanation 1]]
